 residential and light commercial service, which in North America is typically
 rated 120/240 volt. ]]

A 'transformer' is a static electrical device that transfers energy by inductive
coupling between its winding circuits. A varying current in the primary winding
creates a varying magnetic flux in the transformer's core and thus a varying
magnetic flux through the secondary winding. This varying magnetic flux induces
a varying electromotive force (emf) or voltage in the secondary winding.

Transformers range in size from thumbnail-sized used in microphones to units
weighing hundreds of tons interconnecting the power grid. A wide range of
transformer designs are used in electronic and electric power applications.
Transformers are essential for the transmission, distribution, and utilization
of electrical energy.
